awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Northeast Analysis Network
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides funding for participation in the conference "The Northeast Analysis Network" that will be held at University of Connecticut in Fall 2019, University of Rochester in Fall 2020, Syracuse University in Fall 2021, SUNY-Albany in Fall 2022.
 
The conferences focus on recent developments in Analysis, in a broad spectrum of fields including harmonic analysis, dynamical systems, geometric function theory, nonlinear partial differential equations, and operator algebras.   At each conference, there will be two magnet lectures by a leader researcher, and many short talks by junior conference participants.  The organizing committee will strive to make this funding opportunity known to target groups through a number of different activities.   More information will be made available at: https://sites.google.com/site/northeastanalysisnetwork/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This award supported participants (by funding travel and local expenses) in the 2019 edition of the Northeast Analysis Network meeting held at the University of Connecticut in Storrs, CT in September 2019. This regional conference series aimed at early-career researchers (PhD students, postdoctoral researchers, tenure-line assistant professors) in mathematical analysis is a joint venture between SUNY Albany, Syracuse University, University of Connecticut, and University of Rochester. Prior editions of the conference were held in 2016 (inaugural year), 2017, and 2018.

The 2019 conference featured:

  • Two hour "Excelsior Lectures" by Tatiana Toro, Craig McKibben and Sara Merner Professor of Mathematics at University of Washington
  • One hour featured-lecture by Blair Davey, Assistant Professor at City University of New York
  • Ten 20-minute contributed talks by 2 graduate students, 6 postdoctoral researchers or teaching-track assistant professors, 1 tenure-track assistant professor, and 1 tenured professor from 7 different universities.
  • Break times allowing conference participants to network

The conference attracted 51 registered participants, primarily from the northeast United States (Connecticut, Massachusetts, New York, Rhode Island), as well as participants from Colorado, Deleware, Louisiana, Maryland, Pennsylvania, Virginia, and Washington state. About 24% of participants were tenure-line faculty and 76% of participants were graduate students, postdocs, or visiting assistant professors (and 1 undergraduate student).

The research talks convered an array specialties in mathematical analysis and related fields, including analysis on metric spaces, complex analysis, geometric analysis, geometric measure theory, harmonic analysis, partial differential equations, and probability theory.

The titles of the talks presented were:

  • Excelsior Lectures: Elliptic measure and the geometry of domains in Euclidean space
  • Featured Lecture: A quantification of the Besicovitch projection theorem and its generalizations
  • The Schroedinger equation with random time-dependent potential
  • On Szego's theorem for a nonclassical case and its application
  • Parabolic measure
  • Sharp Adams and Hardy-Adams inequalities on hyperbolic spaces
  • Strong and classical solutions to the oblique derivative problem
  • Unique continuation on convex domains
  • Rectifiability of doubling measures in Hilbert space
  • Radon unitary matrices and matrix models for circular beta ensemble
  • Interior estimates for eigenfunctions of the fractional Laplacian on a bounded Euclidean domain
  • Whitney's extension theorems in the Heisenberg group

On conference surveys, 20 participants reported having an opportunity to discuss their research with one or more other mathematicians whom they had not met before.

The future editions of this conference series that are supported by companion awards on this collaborative research grant that were held or will be held are:

  • NAN 2022 - University at Albany (SUNY) - September 2022
  • NAN 2023 - University of Rochester - September 2023 (originally scheduled for Fall 2020, but postponed due to the covid-19 pandemic)
  • NAN 2024 - Syracuse University - September 2024 (originally scheduled for Fall 2021, but postponed due to the covid-19 pandemic)

Last Modified: 03/17/2024
Modified by: Matthew Badger
